member.summary: Specifies the D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE mode to use for resolving a w texture coordinate that is outside the 0 to 1 range.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_STATIC_SAMPLER_DESC.MipLODBias
member.summary: Offset from the calculated mipmap level. For example, if Direct3D calculates that a texture should be sampled at mipmap level 3 and MipLODBias is 2, then the texture will be sampled at mipmap level 5.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_STATIC_SAMPLER_DESC.MaxAnisotropy
member.summary: Clamping value used if D3D12_FILTER_ANISOTROPIC or D3D12_FILTER_COMPARISON_ANISOTROPIC is specified as the filter. Valid values are between 1 and 16.

summary.para: A function that compares sampled data against existing sampled data. The function options are listed in D3D12_COMPARISON_FUNC.
One member of D3D12_STATIC_BORDER_COLOR, the border color to use if D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE_BORDER is specified for AddressU, AddressV, or AddressW. Range must be between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_STATIC_SAMPLER_DESC.MinLOD
member.summary: Lower end of the mipmap range to clamp access to, where 0 is the largest and most detailed mipmap level and any level higher than that is less detailed.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_STATIC_SAMPLER_DESC.MaxLOD
member.summary: Upper end of the mipmap range to clamp access to, where 0 is the largest and most detailed mipmap level and any level higher than that is less detailed. This value must be greater than or equal to MinLOD. To have no upper limit on LOD set this to a large value such as D3D12_FLOAT32_MAX.

summary.para: The ShaderRegister and RegisterSpace parameters correspond to the binding syntax of HLSL. For example, in HLSL:
Texture2D<float4> a : register(t2, space3); This corresponds to a ShaderRegister of 2 (indicating the type is SRV), and RegisterSpace is 3.
The ShaderRegister and RegisterSpace pair is needed to establish correspondence between shader resources and runtime heap descriptors, using the root signature data structure.
See the description for ShaderRegister. Register space is optional; the default register space is 0.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_STATIC_SAMPLER_DESC.ShaderVisibility
member.summary: Specifies the visibility of the sampler to the pipeline shaders, one member of D3D12_SHADER_VISIBILITY.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE
member.summary: Identifies a technique for resolving texture coordinates that are outside of the boundaries of a texture.

remarks.para: This enum is used by the D3D12_SAMPLER_DESC structure.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

summary.para: Tile the texture at every (u,v) integer junction. For example, for u values between 0 and 3, the texture is repeated three times.

Flip the texture at every (u,v) integer junction. For u values between 0 and 1, for example, the texture is addressed normally; between 1 and 2, the texture is flipped (mirrored); between 2 and 3, the texture is normal again; and so on.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE.D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE_CLAMP
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the texture color at 0.0 or 1.0, respectively.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D12.D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE.D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE_BORDER
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the border color specified in D3D12_SAMPLER_DESC or HLSL code.

summary.para: Similar to D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE_MIRROR and D3D12_TEXTURE_ADDRESS_MODE_CLAMP. Takes the absolute value of the texture coordinate (thus, mirroring around 0), and then clamps to the maximum value.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE
member.summary: Driver type options.

remarks.para: The driver type is required when calling D3D11CreateDevice or D3D11CreateDeviceAndSwapChain.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_UNKNOWN
member.summary: The driver type is unknown.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_HARDWARE
member.summary: A hardware driver, which implements Direct3D features in hardware. This is the primary driver that you should use in your Direct3D applications because it provides the best performance. A hardware driver uses hardware acceleration (on supported hardware) but can also use software for parts of the pipeline that are not supported in hardware. This driver type is often referred to as a hardware abstraction layer or HAL.

summary.para:
A reference driver, which is a software implementation that supports every Direct3D feature. A reference driver is designed for accuracy rather than speed and as a result is slow but accurate. The rasterizer portion of the driver does make use of special CPU instructions whenever it can, but it is not intended for retail applications; use it only for feature testing, demonstration of functionality, debugging, or verifying bugs in other drivers. The reference device for this driver is installed by the Windows SDK 8.0 or later and is intended only as a debug aid for development purposes. This driver may be referred to as a REF driver, a reference driver, or a reference rasterizer.
Note When you use the REF driver in Windows Store apps, the REF driver renders correctly but doesn't display any output on the screen. To verify bugs in hardware drivers for Windows Store apps, use D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_WARP for the WARP driver instead.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_NULL
member.summary: A NULL driver, which is a reference driver without render capability. This driver is commonly used for debugging non-rendering API calls, it is not appropriate for retail applications. This driver is installed by the DirectX SDK.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE.D3D_DRIVER_TYPE_SOFTWARE
member.summary: A software driver, which is a driver implemented completely in software. The software implementation is not intended for a high-performance application due to its very slow performance.

summary.para:
A WARP driver, which is a high-performance software rasterizer. The rasterizer supports feature levels 9_1 through level 10_1 with a high performance software implementation. For information about limitations creating a WARP device on certain feature levels, see Limitations Creating WARP and Reference Devices. For more information about using a WARP driver, see Windows Advanced Rasterization Platform (WARP) In-Depth Guide.
Note The WARP driver that Windows 8 includes supports feature levels 9_1 through level 11_1.
Note The WARP driver that Windows 8.1 includes fully supports feature level 11_1, including tiled resources, IDXGIDevice3::Trim, shared BCn surfaces, minblend, and map default.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL
member.summary: Describes the set of features targeted by a Direct3D device.

remarks.para: For an overview of the capabilities of each feature level, see [Direct3D feature levels](/windows/desktop/direct3d11/overviews-direct3d-11-devices-downlevel-intro). For information about limitations creating non-hardware-type devices on certain feature levels, see [Limitations creating WARP and reference devices](/windows/desktop/direct3d11/overviews-direct3d-11-devices-limitations).
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_1_0_CORE
member.summary: Allows Microsoft Compute Driver Model (MCDM) devices to be used, or more feature-rich devices (such as traditional GPUs) that support a superset of the functionality. MCDM is the overall driver model for compute-only; it's a scaled-down peer of the larger scoped Windows Device Driver Model (WDDM).

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_9_1
member.summary: Targets features supported by [feature level](/windows/desktop/direct3d11/overviews-direct3d-11-devices-downlevel-intro) 9.1, including shader model 2.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_9_2
member.summary: Targets features supported by [feature level](/windows/desktop/direct3d11/overviews-direct3d-11-devices-downlevel-intro) 9.2, including shader model 2.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_9_3
member.summary: Targets features supported by [feature level](/windows/desktop/direct3d11/overviews-direct3d-11-devices-downlevel-intro) 9.3, including shader model 2.0b.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_10_0
member.summary: Targets features supported by Direct3D 10.0, including shader model 4.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_10_1
member.summary: Targets features supported by Direct3D 10.1, including shader model 4.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_11_0
member.summary: Targets features supported by Direct3D 11.0, including shader model 5.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_11_1
member.summary: Targets features supported by Direct3D 11.1, including shader model 5 and logical blend operations. This feature level requires a display driver that is at least implemented to WDDM for Windows 8 (WDDM 1.2).

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_12_0
member.summary: Targets features supported by Direct3D 12.0, including shader model 5.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL.D3D_FEATURE_LEVEL_12_1
member.summary: Targets features supported by Direct3D 12.1, including shader model 5.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_PRIMITIVE_TOPOLOGY
member.summary: Values that indicate how the pipeline interprets vertex data that is bound to the input-assembler stage. These primitive topology values determine how the vertex data is rendered on screen.

remarks.para: Use the ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetPrimitiveTopology method and a value from D3D_PRIMITIVE_TOPOLOGY to bind a primitive topology to the input-assembler stage. Use the ID3D11DeviceContext::IAGetPrimitiveTopology method to retrieve the primitive topology for the input-assembler stage. The following diagram shows the various primitive types for a geometry shader object.
This doc was truncated.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_PRIMITIVE_TOPOLOGY.D3D_PRIMITIVE_TOPOLOGY_UNDEFINED
member.summary: The IA stage has not been initialized with a primitive topology. The IA stage will not function properly unless a primitive topology is defined.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_SRV_DIMENSION
member.summary: Values that identify the type of resource to be viewed as a shader resource.

remarks.para: A D3D_SRV_DIMENSION-typed value is specified in the ViewDimension member of the D3D11_SHADER_RESOURCE_VIEW_DESC structure or the Dimension member of the D3D11_SHADER_INPUT_BIND_DESC structure.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Graphics.Direct3D.D3D_SRV_DIMENSION.D3D_SRV_DIMENSION_UNKNOWN
member.summary: The type is unknown.

member.summary: The resource is a buffer.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.S_OK
member.summary: Result was successful / OK

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED
member.summary: You tried to use a resource to which you did not have the required access privileges. This error is most typically caused when you write to a shared resource with read-only access.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_ACCESS_LOST
member.summary: The desktop duplication interface is invalid. The desktop duplication interface typically becomes invalid when a different type of image is displayed on the desktop.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_ALREADY_EXISTS
member.summary: The desired element already exists. This is returned by DXGIDeclareAdapterRemovalSupport if it is not the first time that the function is called.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_CANNOT_PROTECT_CONTENT
member.summary: DXGI can't provide content protection on the swap chain. This error is typically caused by an older driver, or when you use a swap chain that is incompatible with content protection.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_HUNG
member.summary: The application's device failed due to badly formed commands sent by the application. This is an design-time issue that should be investigated and fixed.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_REMOVED
member.summary: The video card has been physically removed from the system, or a driver upgrade for the video card has occurred. The application should destroy and recreate the device. For help debugging the problem, call ID3D10Device::GetDeviceRemovedReason.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_RESET
member.summary: The device failed due to a badly formed command. This is a run-time issue; The application should destroy and recreate the device.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_DRIVER_INTERNAL_ERROR
member.summary: The driver encountered a problem and was put into the device removed state.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_FRAME_STATISTICS_DISJOINT
member.summary: An event (for example, a power cycle) interrupted the gathering of presentation statistics.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_GRAPHICS_VIDPN_SOURCE_IN_USE
member.summary: The application attempted to acquire exclusive ownership of an output, but failed because some other application (or device within the application) already acquired ownership.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_INVALID_CALL
member.summary: The application provided invalid parameter data; this must be debugged and fixed before the application is released.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_MORE_DATA
member.summary: The buffer supplied by the application is not big enough to hold the requested data.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_NAME_ALREADY_EXISTS
member.summary: The supplied name of a resource in a call to DXGI.IResource1.CreateSharedHandle is already associated with some other resource.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_NONEXCLUSIVE
member.summary: A global counter resource is in use, and the Direct3D device can't currently use the counter resource.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_NOT_CURRENTLY_AVAILABLE
member.summary: The resource or request is not currently available, but it might become available later.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_NOT_FOUND
member.summary: When calling DXGI.IObject.GetPrivateData, the GUID passed in is not recognized as one previously passed to DXG.IObject.SetPrivateData or DXGI.IObject.SetPrivateDataInterface. When calling DXGI.IFactory.EnumAdapters or DXGI.IAdapter.EnumOutputs, the enumerated ordinal is out of range.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_REMOTE_CLIENT_DISCONNECTED
member.summary: Reserved

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_REMOTE_OUTOFMEMORY
member.summary: Reserved

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_RESTRICT_TO_OUTPUT_STALE
member.summary: The DXGI output (monitor) to which the swap chain content was restricted is now disconnected or changed.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_SDK_COMPONENT_MISSING
member.summary: The operation depends on an SDK component that is missing or mismatched.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_SESSION_DISCONNECTED
member.summary: The Remote Desktop Services session is currently disconnected.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_UNSUPPORTED
member.summary: The requested functionality is not supported by the device or the driver.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_WAIT_TIMEOUT
member.summary: The time-out interval elapsed before the next desktop frame was available.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.DXGI_ERROR_WAS_STILL_DRAWING
member.summary: The GPU was busy at the moment when a call was made to perform an operation, and did not execute or schedule the operation.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Foundation.RECT
member.summary: The RECT structure defines a rectangle by the coordinates of its upper-left and lower-right corners.

remarks.para: The RECT structure is identical to the RECTL structure.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.RECT.left
member.summary: Specifies the x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.RECT.top
member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.RECT.right
member.summary: Specifies the x-coordinate of the lower-right corner of the rectangle.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Foundation.RECT.bottom
member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the lower-right corner of the rectangle.

member.name: M:Windows.Win32.System.WinRT.IInspectable.GetIids(System.UInt32*,System.Guid**)
member.summary: Gets the interfaces that are implemented by the current Windows Runtime class.

param.name: iidCount
param.para: Type: ULONG* The number of interfaces that are implemented by the current Windows Runtime object, excluding the IUnknown and IInspectable implementations.

param.name: iids
param.para: Type: IID** A pointer to an array that contains an IID for each interface implemented by the current Windows Runtime object. The IUnknown and IInspectable interfaces are excluded.

returns.para: Type: HRESULT This function can return the following values.
This doc was truncated.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: M:Windows.Win32.System.WinRT.IInspectable.GetTrustLevel(Windows.Win32.System.WinRT.TrustLevel*)
member.summary: Gets the trust level of the current Windows Runtime object.

param.name: trustLevel
param.para: Type: TrustLevel* The trust level of the current Windows Runtime object. The default is BaseLevel.

returns.para: Type: HRESULT This method always returns S_OK.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.System.WinRT.TrustLevel
member.summary: Represents the trust level of an activatable class.

remarks.para: Classes can be activated depending on the trust level of the caller and the trust classification of the activatable class.
RegisteredTrustLevel is an alias for this enumeration.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.System.WinRT.TrustLevel.BaseTrust
member.summary: The component has access to resources that are not protected.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.System.WinRT.TrustLevel.PartialTrust
member.summary: The component has access to resources requested in the app manifest and approved by the user.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.System.WinRT.TrustLevel.FullTrust
member.summary: The component requires the full privileges of the user.
